body:
From the comment:

> currently there is a mismatch between https://beta.rclone.org/version.txt and https://beta.rclone.org/rclone-beta-latest-linux-amd64.zip
> 
> version.txt says : "1.54.0-beta.4903.211b08f77"
> 
> the zip-file contains : rclone-v1.53.3-linux-amd64

This is a known oddity in the build process for a point release, which overwrites the current beta.

As soon as another beta gets released it will get overwritten.

The Release process says this

```
  * make startstable
  * NB this overwrites the current beta so we need to do this
  * git co master
  * # cherry pick the changes to the changelog
  * git checkout ${BASE_TAG}-stable docs/content/changelog.md
  * git commit -a -v -m "Changelog updates from Version ${NEW_TAG}"
  * git push
```

So that push obviously didn't work - I wonder whether the point release build was still in progress.

It should be fixed in a moment though.

So in a perfect world we need to stop the build of the point release making a beta, so I'll update the title of this issue to reflect that.

rename.to: build: don't make a beta when building a point release

> Thanks @ncw for the check and the explanation.
> Right now it's fixed, my molecule tests run through.

Great

You aren't the first person to notice this, so I really need to fix this properly.

In the Makefile

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/7078311a844fe7a12b66ff6e632065d20b48b7d2/Makefile#L214-L221

What we need to do is when making the point release (or any release on the stable branch for that matter), don't do the things in the `ifndef BRANCH_PATH` section.

In fact if `RELEASE_TAG` is set we are building a release and if we update the current beta then I think that would be appropriate.

So I think the if statement needs to be something like `if BRANCH_PATH == "" && RELEASE_TAG==""` which in Makefile speak is something like

```Makefile
ifeq ($(and $(BRANCH_PATH),$(RELEASE_TAG)),)
```

This will stop making betas for .0 releases as well as .1 releases but I think that is OK.

I'll give that a go shortly...

I got the above wrong it should be `ifeq ($(or $(BRANCH_PATH),$(RELEASE_TAG)),)` - come back [DeMorgan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Morgan%27s_laws) all is forgiven!

I had a quick look at the code. I've used ansible a small amount in the past so it made some sort of sense.

It is possible for the `version.txt` and the zip files to get out of sync as you've seen. This issue fixes one of them but it has happened before. There is only ever one directory in the .zip file and that will always have the correct version and arch, so you could update the variables from listing that directory, or just assume that there will always be only one directory.

As for other things, you've installed the man page so that is about it I think! Rclone was designed to not need too much installation.

One thought - since your ansible role is the most popular - we could make it an official part of rclone and move it under the `rclone` organisation. If you think that is interesting then I can explain more, but I totally understand if you want to have it in your own GitHub.

Thanks for maintaining the ansible role :-)

1. Ad directories unzipped: I now added a task that removes the temporary directory at each run:
https://github.com/stefangweichinger/ansible-rclone/commit/40ef4cf490ac3be232035799cd99428fb755065d

That helps to avoid having multiple historic subdirs in the temp dir and not being able to compare the version you want to install with the extracted archive. Sure, download everytime, but I think that's OK for now.

You refer to this logic, I assume: right now the role reads that text file from above and fetches the according zip.
You suggest to just download `rclone-current-$xyz.zip` and just see what's in there, right?
Yes, worth a thought.

2. move to `rclone` organization: why not, sounds great ... maybe more co-work there and more eyes reviewing the changes.
The role name on ansible galaxy would change then, this leads to issues for users, I assume.
